Description: Previous work from our group has shown that luminal B breast cancer subtype is the most prevalent in Colombian women and identified some genes in their tumors that seem to be associated with their ancestral fraction. Our goal was to perform the same type of genomic analysis in a different group of women, diagnosed with the same breast cancer subtype, but with a different ancestral fraction, to find similarities and differences in the expression profile of the tumors. Using samples from women from Puerto Rico, we performed RNA-seq in PAM50 confirmed luminal B breast cancer and found that the size of the tumors was associated with differential gene expression. We also found that BMI, ancestral fraction and tumor size correlated with the predicted infiltration of  different types of immune cells.
SearchResultBody: ME46. Luminal B Breast Cancer Genomics in Hispanic/Latinas: A Window to Tumor Size and Immune Infiltration
Title: Luminal B Breast Cancer Genomics in Hispanic/Latinas: A Window to Tumor Size and Immune Infiltration
